document_title: Utilization of single‐image normalized difference vegetation index (SI‐NDVI) for early plant stress detection
summary_full: This study introduces and validates a simplified imaging technique, Single-Image Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (SI-NDVI), for early detection of plant stress in controlled environments. The SI-NDVI method utilizes a modified camera with a dual bandpass filter to capture both visible (blue) and near-infrared (NIR) light reflectance in a single image, allowing for cost-effective and user-friendly analysis compared to traditional NDVI or hyperspectral imaging. The system was tested on Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings subjected to salinity stress and Eruca sativa plants under ammonium nitrate treatment. Results demonstrated that SI-NDVI could detect stress within 15 minutes of salinity application and within 6 hours of ammonium nitrate exposure, significantly before visual symptoms appeared. The analysis involves processing images with open-source software like Fiji to generate qualitative false-color images and quantitative graphs tracking changes in SI-NDVI values over time. This technique holds promise for applications in indoor farming, high-throughput screening, and space biology by enabling rapid and early identification of plant stress.
key_findings: SI-NDVI imaging can detect plant stress in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings within 15 minutes of salinity application, prior to visual detection.
SI-NDVI imaging can detect stress in Eruca sativa plants within 6 hours of ammonium nitrate treatment, before visual symptoms are apparent.
The SI-NDVI method is simpler and more cost-efficient than traditional dual-image NDVI or hyperspectral imaging.
SI-NDVI analysis can be performed using readily available, open-source software (Fiji) and standard spreadsheet programs (Excel).
The system allows for both qualitative (false-color images) and quantitative (graphs of pixel values) analysis of plant health.
future_research_fields: Characterization of SI-NDVI phenotypes for a wider range of plant stressors, species, and growth mediums.
Deployment of the SI-NDVI method in real-world controlled crop cultivation settings.
Further development and validation of SI-NDVI for high-throughput screening applications.
Application of SI-NDVI for monitoring plant health in space-based agriculture.

conclusions: The SI-NDVI imaging system provides a cost-effective and user-friendly method for early detection of plant stress in controlled environments, enabling interventions before visual symptoms manifest. This technique has significant potential for applications in indoor farming, laboratory plant studies, and potentially space-based agriculture.
impact_statement: This study presents a simplified and affordable imaging technique that allows for the rapid, early detection of plant stress, which is crucial for optimizing crop yields in controlled environments and for future space exploration.
